body: I'm getting ready to put together a release candidate for 1.9.0; reading through the history, I'm not sure this one is going to make it... if it doesn't make it in 1.9.0, I think it should be bumped to 2.0, because it adds a new feature.
That sounds good. I haven't had a chance to get back to this and address Keith's point about impacting balancing. Thanks.

The Corrupted STDOUT issue should be fixed in 3.0.0-M1 (2.20.1 is our current version, and 2.21.0 is the version that fixes the problem, but creates the corrupted STDOUT)

https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SUREFIRE-1498
I have a half baked idea about the balancing issue, I will try to write it up tomorrow for discussion.

How would you guys feel about targeting a 1.9.1? I think this should be considered a bug fix but I don't see it being completed in the next few days. My project ran into a frequently recurring ConcurrentModificationException that prevented master from balancing due to the slow-reporting tserver statuses on a large cluster.

1.9.1 is fine for a target. It may depend on how the final implementation changes the public API or other user-facing components, though. It may also depend on how risky/disruptive the final implementation is.
Merged as 63697e7aad74bb6491dffb4dc8876f073237fde2

Fixed in fbaee3e76438202752c03d18dfcc31fb664c5ce6 for master/2.0
Fixed in b8c19f8335d18ea02dbdddb9155066859894259e for 1.9.0

I did see a ShellServletIT failure, but it appears that this isn't a new failure and is unrelated.

I added a second commit which instructs the server-side to use TLS 1.2 by default, also. As I understand it, there's a few well-known downgrade attacks for 1.1 and 1.0, that we should avoid. Since we maintain the code for both client and server, there's no reason we shouldn't use 1.2 by default. It is still configurable, if users need something else.
Is there an intent to remove ProtocolOverridingSSLSocketFactory as well?

I prototyped my half baked idea. The prototype can be found in commit keith-turner@5044241ca445a0bbc48e38931f09f77d8acb44b9  which is in the branch [keith-turner/ACCUMULO-4615](https://github.com/keith-turner/accumulo/tree/ACCUMULO-4615).  I am not proposing we do this, just posting it for consideration.  The concept needs to be tested on a busy cluster.

I say this idea is half baked because I have never used the thrift send and recv method separately.  I suspect it may work well, but I am not sure.  I think in the case where a tablet server is using THsHaServer it may work really well because there is a dedicated thread to accept connections (even if all threads in the servers thread pool for processing connections are busy).  However in the case where the tserver uses the TThreadPoolServer (this is used when Kerberos is used and it can also be configured) there is no dedicated thread to accept connections, so the send call from the master may block if all server threads are busy (I am not sure).  A dedicated thrift server and port for getting status in tablet servers would solve this issue.

A completely different way of solving this issue may be to use the thrift async client which uses non-blocking sockets for connections.  However I Am not sure how well this would work with SSL and Kerberos and I have never used the thrift async client.  I am interested in learning more about it though, but have not yet found the time to do so.
Resolved conflicts in PR with updated 1.8 branch.
@PircDef Maybe... that would be a bigger change, and more testing to ensure correctness. This is a simple configuration defaults change vs. changing currently functioning code.
Could add a method to NewTableConfiguration instead of adding a method to tableOperations

I thought that would have been a possible fix as well, but ended up going Adam's suggestion. If you feel it is worth it for possible future needs I can refactor the method to once again return boolean but with true after the queuing.

It's up to you. Idle compactions never took into account other tserver activity, like scans, so they were probably never a good idea... but I defer to you, or another reviewer's judgment... I'm mostly indifferent.
I'll leave it as is unless someone else has other thoughts.

@keith-turner RE: Your new thrift server. I'm not really too savvy with thrift. I'll have to do some poking around to understand it more. But the idea sounds reasonable to me. We still have the open question about what is appropriate when we cannot reach a tserver for its status in a timely manner (the onTimeout() case). 

What do you think about tracking "notReached" tservers in this scenario and delaying balancing rather than incrementing the badServers count (so we don't eventually kill it)?

Not sure why this failed in jenkins. The error seems to be about:

I ran with verify, and hadnt changed any formatting. I re-ran with verify after the error locally and did not get an error.

@alerman Thanks for the PR.  I will take a look at this and hopefully we can get this in the 1.9/1.8 release.  Just a heads up, since we are now using GitHub issues, you don't have to create an issue for something minor since a pull request is considered an issue.

@ctubbsii should know why your Jenkins build is failing... it appears related to recent changes to the formatter.

@alerman Default to descending makes sense to me for most columns, except for the name field. I'm not sure how easy it would be to make the default sort order different for different columns.

The monitor has undergone a lot of work in the current development branch. Sorting is now much cheaper, and client-side. Have you had a chance to see if this issue affects the latest version in our 2.0 development branch / master?
The jenkins failure looks like a network failure on the build infrastructure, nothing to do with your PR or the recent formatting changes.

I'm currently prepping a 1.9.0 release candidate. Since this one isn't currently working, it's not going to make it, and I'm not sure we should change the behavior in a bugfix release. Also, the monitor is completely different in the master branch, so any fix here won't apply going forward.

If the 1.9.0 release candidate passes, I'm not sure if it would be worth considering this for 1.9.1... or leave it as-is and focus on making improvements to the monitor in the master branch.

I finally got it running but didn't have time left to make the changes. What is the release time line for 2.0? If it is relatively soon I wont bother with an update for this PR. If it will be longer I will update this PR with the changes as requested
@alerman We don't have a strict timeline for 2.0... but I was hoping for late summer.
@ctubbsii ok I will create a PR for 2.0 once I have gotten my environment working.

Thanks @alerman.  This looks good to me.  I was trying to think of an easy way to indicate the different default behavior of the columns to the user but couldn't come up with anything.  I think the difference in behavior is intuitive between the columns having text or numbers.
Was Monitor 2.0 a lot more pleasant to work with?

The shell works if you pass all information in via the command line or use accumulo-client.properties. However, maybe this is a bug in that something is missing and a better error message should be printed.

The reason this error is occurring for you is that the shell used to get Accumulo instance information (ie. instance name & zookeepers) from the accumulo-site.xml which is bad practice.  This info now needs to be passed in on command line or set in accumulo-client.properties.  If update Uno, it will set up this file.  See commit below:

https://github.com/astralway/uno/commit/8fbe10a9cd9e12f5eca67ee09cfad62aef141eb5
Good call.  I didn't have latest Uno updates.  Closing.

> I'm not sure what to do from here.

I think the following needs to be done.

 * Determine how one process can close a file using GCSC such that any other processes writing to the file will fail.  Then implement this as a `org.apache.accumulo.server.master.recovery.LogCloser`.
 * Put this implementation on Accumulo classpath
 * Set the accumulo property `master.walog.closer.implementation` to use the impl

I am really curious about the overall write ahead log behavior with GCSC.  It would be interesting to intentionally kill tablet servers and see if the data recovers correctly.
Looking at GCS, that WAL file doesn't even exist, so I'm not sure where it's storing that upon restar. Is it somewhere in zookeeper I can wipe out, at least to temporarily negate this issue?

> Is it somewhere in zookeeper I can wipe out, at least to temporarily negate this issue?

Try looking in `/accumulo/<uuid>/root_tablet/walogs` in zookeeper.

I'm not sure there's a general solution in Accumulo we can provide for this scenario. We can't really know how to react to unknown `FileSystem` implementations. If it's not one of the ones we support, the user must provide a LogCloser implementation for that specific `FileSystem`.

This is really more of a question, than an issue. I'm inclined to close it as answered. Does that seem reasonable?

`connector.tableOperations().flush("tableName", null, null, true); `

..which is awkward.
Unable to reproduce this error.

Below are some notes I took while debugging this.  There were ~600K missing rows out of 24 billion.  I focused on one missing row `0481452f58dcde67` and using continuous ingest analysis tools I found :
 
* The missing row was written between 18:56:46 and 18:57:05 on 4/23 to tablet `2;0500ec;0480ed`.
* Tablet `2;0500ec;0480ed` was assigned to tserver `worker3` at the time.

The following are selected logs messages from the tserver on worker 3.

```
# Begins using WAL 27cb640d-0865-4174-9226-804965ca39f3
2018-04-23 18:55:42,270 [log.TabletServerLogger] INFO : Using next log hdfs://leader1:8020/accumulo/wal/worker3+9997/27cb640d-0865-4174-9226-804965ca39f3

# last successful minor compaction of tablet before tserver is killed
2018-04-23 18:56:54,266 [tabletserver.LargestFirstMemoryManager] DEBUG: COMPACTING 2;0500ec;0480ed  total = 957,588,936 ingestMemory = 957,588,936
2018-04-23 18:56:55,822 [tablet.MinorCompactor] DEBUG: Begin minor compaction hdfs://leader1:8020/accumulo/tables/2/t-00005rd/F0000pzl.rf_tmp 2;0500ec;0480ed
2018-04-23 18:57:00,158 [tablet.Compactor] DEBUG: Compaction 2;0500ec;0480ed 158,183 read | 158,183 written | 44,811 entries/sec |  3.530 secs |    6,261,323 bytes | 1773745.892 byte/sec
2018-04-23 18:57:00,181 [tablet.Tablet] DEBUG: Logs for memory compacted: 2;0500ec;0480ed worker3:9997/hdfs://leader1:8020/accumulo/wal/worker3+9997/27cb640d-0865-4174-9226-804965ca39f3
2018-04-23 18:57:00,181 [tablet.Tablet] DEBUG: Logs for memory compacted: 2;0500ec;0480ed worker3:9997/hdfs://leader1:8020/accumulo/wal/worker3+9997/bf2e3788-e3ca-4ae3-bc1a-b89a3cdbe6b6
2018-04-23 18:57:00,181 [tablet.Tablet] DEBUG: Logs for current memory: 2;0500ec;0480ed worker3:9997/hdfs://leader1:8020/accumulo/wal/worker3+9997/27cb640d-0865-4174-9226-804965ca39f3
2018-04-23 18:57:00,181 [tablet.Tablet] DEBUG: Logs to be destroyed: 2;0500ec;0480ed worker3:9997/hdfs://leader1:8020/accumulo/wal/worker3+9997/bf2e3788-e3ca-4ae3-bc1a-b89a3cdbe6b6

# Begin using WAL ee2bd18d-9d37-4eee-89a9-b15f477063ac
2018-04-23 18:57:00,351 [log.TabletServerLogger] INFO : Using next log hdfs://leader1:8020/accumulo/wal/worker3+9997/ee2bd18d-9d37-4eee-89a9-b15f477063ac

# another minor compaction starts
2018-04-23 18:58:15,115 [tabletserver.LargestFirstMemoryManager] DEBUG: COMPACTING 2;0500ec;0480ed  total = 986,606,421 ingestMemory = 717,298,555

# wal is marked unreferenced
2018-04-23 18:58:17,587 [tserver.TabletServer] INFO : Marking hdfs://leader1:8020/accumulo/wal/worker3+9997/27cb640d-0865-4174-9226-804965ca39f3 as unreferenced

#tablet server is killed before compaction finishes
```

Later the tablet is loaded on worker 4 and even though the tablet has data in wal `27cb640d-0865-4174-9226-804965ca39f3`, it is not used for recovery.


It looks like the 2.9.0 and 3.0.2 binary distributions of Hadoop were not built with Zstandard library.  So this will require building Hadoop with -Pdist,native and -Drequire.zstd flags.
The fix is in `SaslConnectionParams`.  The code will now get a default value of `accumulo` if the Kerberos primary is not set.

I determined the cause of this bug.  It happens when a tablet is unloaded from a tserver and then later comes back. When it comes back, if data is written and no minor compaction occurs before the tserver dies then that data may not be seen.  Below is a detailed example, the seq# below are WAL seq#.

 * TabletA is loaded on tserver5
 * Define tablet is written to WAL1 with seq#1
 * TabletA is loaded on tserver5 for a bit and many compactions occur
 * Data is written to WAL1 for tabletA with seq# 50
 * TabletA is compacted
   * compaction start is written to WAL with seq# 51
   * compaction finish is writtent to WAL with seq# 52
 * TabletA is unloaded from tserver5
 * tserver5 starts using WAL2, however WAL1 is still referenced by other tablets
 * TabletA is loaded from tserver5
 * Define tablet is written to WAL2 with seq#1
 * Data is written to WAL2 for TabletA with seq# 1 (the seq# is lower because it resets when tablet is reassigned)
 * tserver5 dies

During recovery of TabletA WAL1 and WAL2 are examined to find the last compaction to finish and its seq#.  The last compaction to finish has a seq# of 52, therefore we look for data >= 52.  However the data in WAL2 has a lower seq# and is therefore ignored.

Before 1.8.0 WAL1 would never have been included in the recovery and this problem would not have occurred.  However the changes made in 1.8.0 (moved from tracking WAL refs per tablet to per tablet server) bring WAL1 into the recovery process.  

Notes from tracking down bug : [accumulo-449.txt](https://github.com/apache/accumulo/files/1956811/accumulo-449.txt)
See https://github.com/apache/accumulo-website/pull/80 for updates to documentation
The more I thought about it, the less I like changing the default behavior of API. For now, I will merge this change as is.

Tips for building Hadoop (I was able to build 2.9.0 on Fedora 27):

- Required manual compilation and install of [Protocol buffers 2.5.0]( https://github.com/google/protobuf/releases/tag/v2.5.0). First did a "dnf remove protobuf-compiler" to make things easier.
- Will fail to build with OpenSSL 1.1.0 so either [patch](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/HADOOP-14597) or use 1.0.2
- Fedora packages required: cmake openssl-devel make automake gcc gcc-c++ libzstd 
libzstd-devel

It looks the TravisCI build is failing but it looks like its due to a bug in master (unrelated to your code) that was fixed.  You should rebase your branch with master using steps below:

```
git checkout master
git fetch upstream
git pull upstream master
git checkout <your branch>
git rebase master
git push -f origin <your branch>
```

MiniAccumulo reads the classpath from classloaders because it launches subprocesses which need a classpath.  The non public API for MiniAccumulo allows explicitly setting this classpath as config, would it be helpful to make this public?
Sounds like a good solution in this buggy case! Thanks for a quick reply.

> Sounds like a good solution in this buggy case!

So for your testing case, you could easily know what classpath to use?

Yes. Or I can reproduce the logic from the [getClasspath()](https://github.com/apache/accumulo/blob/rel/1.9.1/minicluster/src/main/java/org/apache/accumulo/minicluster/impl/MiniAccumuloClusterImpl.java#L231) function but with an extra skip of `bad` loader(s).

Ok.  At [MiniAccumuloClusterImpl.java#L252](https://github.com/apache/accumulo/blob/rel/1.9.1/minicluster/src/main/java/org/apache/accumulo/minicluster/impl/MiniAccumuloClusterImpl.java#L252) you can see where it checks this internal config.   This can be set using [MiniAccumuloConfigImp.setClasspathItems()](https://github.com/apache/accumulo/blob/rel/1.9.1/minicluster/src/main/java/org/apache/accumulo/minicluster/impl/MiniAccumuloConfigImpl.java#L597).  You could experiment with using that internal API, however since its not Public API there is no guarantee of stability.

@bbux-atg  thanks for the contribution.  I have one reservation about this change and that is exposing internal types like Session to user pluggable code.  Developers currently change internal types as needed and my not be aware that they are breaking plugins.  I think it would be best to introduce a new type that the pluggable code compares.  If you would like I can make a pass at introducing this type, just let me know.
@keith-turner I am trying to port this over on behalf of other users.  I will defer to you for the best approach.  Please proceed at a first pass with the alternate type. Thanks.

The problem was that the underlying code was not always throwing a LogClosedException and instead was letting the ClosedChannelException to pass through.  This was bypassing the code that was to avoid waiting when the underlying log was closed.  Note that I added the caching of the ClosedChannelException as well in that circumstance in case I did not translate ClosedChannelException to a LogClosedException everywhere.  That part could probably be dropped if someone can validate that the translation is complete.
